chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: In this problem, we will create a corporate tax table to solve for the succeeding questions.

A corporate tax table is basically a table which shows the tax rate depending on the range of the taxable income. In the table, we will input the upper and lower limit of the tax bracket. On the next row, we will input the computation for that bracket. 

Since taxes here are paid progressively, then only the difference between the excess and the lower limit will be subjected to the increase in tax.

**a.** In this table, we can see the corresponding tax for each bracket. 
[![Screen-Shot-2022-04-24-at-12-54-49.png](https://i.postimg.cc/8CSD4vgL/Screen-Shot-2022-04-24-at-12-54-49.png)](https://postimg.cc/k2fkXB45)
As you can see from the table above, the tax is computed by multiplying the difference between the excess and the upper limit of the previous bracket.
**b.** For a taxable income of $\$1,350,000$, the marginal tax rate is $34\%$ since it falls between the range of $\$335,001$ to $\$10,000,000$

**c.** For a taxable income of $\$1,350,000$ the total tax can be solved by subtracting the lower limit of its bracket from the income and multiplying it to the tax rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Marginal tax}&=(\$1,350,000-\$335,000) \times 0.34\\[15 pt]
&=\$345,100
\end{aligned}$$

The tax at this bracket is $\$345,100$

We will then take this then add the tax for the previous brackets.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax}&=\$7,500+\$6,250+\$8,500\\
&+\$91,650+\$345,100\\[15 pt]
&=\$459,000
\end{aligned}$$

The tax at this income is $\$459,000$

**c.** To get the average tax rate, we will simply get the tax and divide it by the taxable income.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax rate}&=\dfrac{\$459,000}{\$1,350,000}\\[15 pt]
&=0.34
\end{aligned}$$

The average tax rate is $0.34$ or $34\%$
